Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integrated Development of Scalable Mobile Multidisciplinary Modules (SM3) for STEM Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The central idea in this project is to motivate students to pursue studies in STEM areas by creating and disseminating scalable modules that demonstrate in a compelling manner how math and engineering theory enables modern applications such as those embedded in wireless devices. The goal is to motivate graduates to create high-tech products, enter the high-tech workforce, and become innovators. This project will promote a transformative STEM education agenda by developing and disseminating innovative and scalable content for several courses. These innovative products will promote a positive attitude change towards learning STEM concepts by continuously fusing theory with high tech applications. Objectives include developing a diverse community of users, innovative products with mobile video-streamed content, software training modules for skill building, e-books, and training workshops. The PIs will create and disseminate products on multidisciplinary STEM applications in areas including engineering, arts and media, and earth systems.

The innovative educational modules will have comprehensive multidisciplinary content to address diverse audiences. Modules will be packaged for mobile delivery and will be multipurpose, multidisciplinary, and will: a) motivate students to learn theory through compelling applications, b) engage students in implementation for skill building and workforce creation purposes, and c) immerse diverse audiences and stakeholders in hands-on workshops for outreach, retention, and recruitment purposes. This project is based on collaboration between ASU and Clarkson University and engages faculty from Johns Hopkins University, Phoenix College, St. Lawrence University, Prairie View A&M University, and Corona del Sol high school. The project will use a mixed-method assessment process (qualitative and quantitative data collection) to build an understanding of the impact of the use of the modules, apps, and other tools on student learning gains, from the individual concept level to more general knowledge about scientific and engineering habits of mind and research practice. Assessments will be done through electronic web tools, pre- and post- quizzes, presentations, one-to-one interviews, and ordinary in-class testing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative IUSE program created significant educational technology innovations, education and training modules, software and other content in sensors and machine learning.  The program first created HTML 5 secure online signal processing software which was freely disseminated to students at several universities.  A unique feature of the software was functions in machine learning which were used to train students in our classes as well as instructors and practitioners.  The software was also used in workforce development programs such as the REU, RET and IRES that trained participants in machine learning algorithms. Results and assessments of the software and all modules have been presented and published in IEEE FIE and ASEE conferences and the ASEE computers in education journal.  Our collaboration with Clarkson university also created smartphone mobile software for echolocation which was also disseminated to undergraduate students and published in the ASEE education journal.

Modules created included significant extensions to other disciplines including nanopore sensors,  solar energy systems, and voice processing. Two mobile versions of our software in Android and iOS were updated in 2018 and disseminated.  These apps are available for free download on Android and iOS sites.   IUSE education modules created include:

a) machine learning primer;
b) social implications of the deployment of sensors and machine learning;
c) positive unlabeled learning module;
d) linear prediction of speech module;
e) voice recognition module;
f) adaptive filter module.

All the above modules were accompanied by hands-on software functions that were used in our classes and training sessions.  A broad assessment of these products and practices was conducted at ASU and Clarkson and results were reported in education conferences. The project included a) comprehensive national and international dissemination of the software and associated IUSE modules, b) annual IUSE workshops that trained faculty, students and practitioners to work with machine learning algorithms and software, c) development of online laboratory exercises for DSP and signals and systems courses, d) development and assessment of IUSE content for use in workforce development programs, and e) a final IUSE workshop in April 2021 summarizing all module content, results, and software.

The collaborative nature of the project helped establish a national and international community of users. In addition to signal processing and machine learning products, this project produced multidisciplinary echolocation products at Clarkson University.

Specific outcomes and products of the program include:

- new online HTML-5 Java-DSP (J-DSP) software deployed in 2017 and used in classes, tutorials and workforce development programs;

- updated versions of iOS iPhone/iPad and Android apps in 2018 which are freely accessible;

- an echolocation app that is available on Google Play. The app was used for UG education;

- annual IUSE training and dissemination workshops and a final IUSE workshop in April 2021;

- outreach at the Corona Del Sol high school in Tempe;

- several publications in IEEE and ASEE conferences.
